title: Google and OpenAI fight over a high-school math competition
Capturing Emerging Market Growth through Developed Market Leaders
summary: A common question we hear from investors is whether they’re missing out by focusing on developed markets like the US or Europe, especially when growth in countries such as China or India appears far more dynamic. Another concern: Is the US market overvalued?
fullContent: A common question we hear from investors is whether they’re missing out by focusing on developed markets like the US or Europe, especially when growth in countries such as China or India appears far more dynamic. Another concern: Is the US market overvalued? Should we be looking elsewhere? In this insightful webinar, we explore these questions using real-world examples and market data and answer: • Why selected developed market companies have consistently captured the most profitable parts of emerging market growth—often outpacing local firms in value creation. • How the “real” valuation of the US market compares to other global markets. How should investors interpret valuations metrics in broader context, and what role should other geographies play? • A brief review of our portfolio’s positioning, and how we are navigating today’s macroeconomic and valuation environment. Interested to know more about Global Investing? Connect with us. https://marcellus.in/connect/?utm_source=Yt&utm_me

title: DP20478 Workers’ Motivation and Quality of Services in Mission-Driven Sectors
summary: This paper studies how firms’ ownership choices and workers’ intrinsic motivation jointly shape service quality and market outcomes in labor-intensive, mission-driven sectors. Two organizations first choose whether to operate as standard for-profit or as mission-oriented firms,...

title: DP20479 Eurosclerosis at 40: Labor Market Institutions, Dynamism, and European Competitiveness
summary: This paper explores a repositioning of Europe’s labor market institutions as potential drivers of the transatlantic gap in macroeconomic performance. Institutional diagnoses were prominent in times of high European unemployment in the 1980-90s.

title: DP20480 The Impact of Debt and Deficits on Long Term Interest Rates in the US
summary: We present new evidence on the impact of fiscal variables on long-term interest rates and term premia in the United States. To alleviate endogeneity problems, we follow the seminal methodology by Laubach (2009) and resort to long-term projections of interest rates and fiscal...

title: DP20477 Opting Out of Centralized Collective Bargaining: Evidence from Italy
summary: This paper presents micro-empirical evidence on the effects of wage-setting decentralization. Our setting is Italy, where employers are required to comply with occupation- and industry-specific wage floors set by national collective bargaining agreements.
